https://s3.amazonaws.com/prod-ucs-content-store-us-east/content/pii:S2095495616000334/STRIPIN/image/gif/1231f44e8fa974292efcf55bbe59b831/si1.gif si1 si1.gif gif 480 17 121 ALTIMG JECHEM 109 S2095-4956(16)00033-4 10.1016/j.jechem.2016.01.023 Science Press and Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics Fig. 1 XRD patterns of OCNTs, RuO2/OCNTs, NCNTs, and RuO2/NCNTs. Fig 1 Fig. 2 Representative TEM images and corresponding particle size distributions of RuO2/OCNTs (a,c), and RuO2/NCNTs (b,d). Particle size distributions were obtained by measuring 200–230 particles. Fig 2 Fig. 3 H2-TPR profiles of RuO2/OCNTs and RuO2/NCNTs. The heating rate was 2°C/min. Fig 3 Fig. 4 XP C 1 s and Ru 3d spectra (a), and Ru 3p spectra (b) of RuO2/OCNTs and RuO2/NCNTs. The spectra were normalized to the corresponding C 1 s peaks and plotted in the same scale for comparison. (c) Relative concentrations of ruthenium species obtained by deconvolution of the XP Ru 3p 3/2 spectra. Fig 4 Fig. 5 XP O 1 s (a,b) and N 1 s (c) spectra of CNTs before and after RuO2 loading. The spectra were normalized to the corresponding C 1 s peaks and plotted in the same scale for comparison. Fig 5 Fig. 6 (a) CVs recorded at 100mV/s without electrode rotation, (b) anodic LSV recorded at 5mV/s for RuO2/OCNTs, RuO2/NCNTs, OCNTs, and NCNTs, (c) the corresponding Tafel plots obtained from LSV recorded at 1mV/s (Measurement conditions: 1600rpm, 0.1M KOH), (d) Nyquist plots (EIS measurements were recorded in 0.1M KOH at open circuit potential using ac perturbation of 10mV and scanning from 50kHz to 10Hz). Fig 6 Fig. 7 Stability studies: (a) chronopotentiometric response recorded at 3mA/cm2; CVs recorded at 100mV/s during the stability tests of OCNTs (b) and NCNTs (c). Measurement conditions: 1600rpm, 0.1M KOH. Fig 7 Fig. 8 Stability studies: (a) chronopotentiometric response recorded at 3mA/cm2; CVs recorded at 100mV/s during the stability tests for RuO2/OCNTs (b) and RuO2/NCNTs (c). Measurement conditions: 1600rpm, 0.1M KOH. Fig 8 Table 1 Elemental analysis and BET surface area (A BET) of CNT substrates and RuO2/CNT composites. Promoting effect of nitrogen doping on carbon nanotube-supported RuO2 applied in the electrocatalytic oxygen evolution reaction Kunpeng Xie a c Wei Xia a Justus Masa b Fengkai Yang a Philipp Weide a Wolfgang Schuhmann b Martin Muhler a d * a Laboratory of Industrial Chemistry, Ruhr-University Bochum, 44780 Bochum, Germany Laboratory of Industrial Chemistry Ruhr-University Bochum Bochum 44780 Germany b Analytical Chemistry–Center for Electrochemical Sciences (CES), Ruhr-University Bochum, 44780 Bochum, Germany Analytical Chemistry–Center for Electrochemical Sciences (CES) Ruhr-University Bochum Bochum 44780 Germany c Competence Centre for Catalysis, Chemical Engineering, Chalmers University of Technology, Gothenburg 41296, Sweden Competence Centre for Catalysis Chemical Engineering Chalmers University of Technology Gothenburg 41296 Sweden d Max Planck Institute for Chemical Energy Conversion, 45470 Mülheiman der Ruhr, Germany Max Planck Institute for Chemical Energy Conversion Mülheiman der Ruhr 45470 Germany * Corresponding author. RuO2 nanoparticles supported on multi-walled carbon nanotubes (CNTs) functionalized with oxygen (OCNTs) and nitrogen (NCNTs) were employed for the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) in 0.1M KOH. The catalysts were synthesized by metal-organic chemical vapor deposition using ruthenium carbonyl (Ru3(CO)12) as Ru precursor. The obtained RuO2/OCNT and RuO2/NCNT composites were characterized using TEM, H2-TPR, XRD and XPS in order probe structure–activity correlations, particularly, the effect of the different surface functional groups on the electrochemical OER performance. The electrocatalytic activity and stability of the catalysts with mean RuO2 particle sizes of 13–14nm was evaluated by linear sweep voltammetry, cyclic voltammetry, and chronopotentiometry, showing that the generation of nitrogen-containing functional groups on CNTs was beneficial for both OER activity and stability. In the presence of RuO2, carbon corrosion was found to be significantly less severe. Graphical abstract Oxygen evolution reaction: RuO2 prevents carbon from severe corrosion. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Ruthenium dioxide Chemical vapor deposition Nitrogen-doped carbon nanotubes Oxygen evolution reaction 1 Introduction Hydrogen production by water electrolysis using renewable electricity has been proposed as an eco-friendly route for energy storage [1]. However, the sluggish kinetics of the oxygen evolution reaction (OER), which is the anode reaction in water electrolysis, remains a major challenge for the development of electrolysers [2]. Ti-supported RuO2, IrO2, or their mixtures are used as dimensionally stable anodes in current industrial processes [3]. Non-precious metal oxides, such as MnO x , Co3O4, as well as Mn- and Co-based mixed oxides have been shown to be promising alternatives to noble metal catalysts [4–9]. However, the poor electrical conductivity of these oxides hinders their large scale applications in water electrolysis. Despite of its high cost, RuO2 remains one of the most promising electrocatalysts for the OER due to its low overpotential and high activity [10–12]. Considering large scale industrial applications, it is necessary to use a conductive support to minimize the amount of RuO2 and lower the electrode cost while simultaneously maintaining the high activity of RuO2. Multi-walled carbon nanotubes (CNTs) have shown great potential as support materials in heterogeneous catalysis and electrocatalysis due to their high electrical conductivity and chemical stability under corrosive conditions [13,14]. Nitrogen doping can significantly modify the electronic and chemical properties of CNTs [15]. RuO2 exhibits a very low overpotential during the OER thus avoiding severe carbon oxidation at high potentials [16], which is of great importance for practical applications especially in polymer electrolyte membrane cells and metal-air batteries. In this work, two types of CNTs including oxygen- and nitrogen-functionalized CNTs were used as support for the deposition of RuO2 nanoparticles by metal-organic chemical vapor deposition (MOCVD). The obtained composites were used as electrocatalysts for the OER under alkaline conditions. The electrocatalytic activity was evaluated by linear sweep voltammetry while the stability was monitored by chronopotentiometry as well as cyclic voltammetry. The results revealed that RuO2 nanoparticles supported on NCNTs (RuO2/NCNTs) are superior both in terms of activity and stability to those supported on OCNT (RuO2/OCNTs) for the OER, which clearly suggests that nitrogen doping promotes the performance of RuO2. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of catalyst CNTs (Baytubes® C 150 P) with mean outer diameter of 15nm and mean inner diameter of 4nm were provided by Bayer Material Science (Leverkusen, Germany). The as-received CNTs were purified by washing in 1.5M HNO3 under stirring at room temperature for 72h in order to remove the residual growth catalysts used in their synthesis. The purified CNTs were partially oxidized by HNO3 vapor at 200°C for 72h to obtain oxygen-functionalized CNTs (OCNTs) [17]. The obtained OCNTs were further treated at 400°C for 6h in 10 vol% NH3 in He with a total flow of 50sccm to obtain nitrogen-functionalized CNTs (NCNTs) [18]. The OCNTs and NCNTs were used as substrates for the deposition of RuO2 nanoparticles. CNT-supported RuO2 nanoparticles were synthesized via a MOCVD procedure using ruthenium carbonyl (Ru3(CO)12) as the Ru precursor [19]. Briefly, about 500mg of CNTs (i.e. OCNTs or NCNTs) and a certain amount of Ru3(CO)12 were mixed and ground for 30min at room temperature to achieve homogeneous mixing. The theoretical loading of Ru was 10.0 wt% in all the cases. The mixture was loaded into a horizontal quartz tube reactor, which was heated following a multiple-step program: room temperature to 40°C at 2°C/min, hold for 60min; 40–60°C at 0.2°C/min, hold for 60min; 60–120°C at 1°C/min, hold for 60min; 120–300°C at 2.8°C/min, hold for 120min; cooling down to room temperature [19]. Synthetic air at atmospheric pressure was used as the reaction gas at a flow rate of 10sccm during the whole temperature program. The obtained samples are denoted as RuO2/OCNTs and RuO2/NCNTs, respectively. 2.2 Characterization XRD was performed using a PANalytical theta–theta powder diffractometer with a Cu K α source. Scans were run from 10° to 80° with a step size of 0.013°. The obtained XRD patterns were analyzed by PANalytical X'Pert HighScore Plus v3.0 software. For elemental analysis, the samples were dissolved in a H2SO4/HCl solution. The Ru content was measured by inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES, PU701 UNICAM). N2 physisorption measurements were conducted at –196°C using an Autosorb-1 MP Quantachrome system. Prior to the measurements, all samples were degassed at 200°C for 2h. The surface areas were calculated from the linear part of the BET plots. The structure of the as-prepared samples was examined using transmission electron microscopy (TEM) with a Tecnai microscope. The diameter distribution was obtained by counting 200–230 particles in several TEM images. Temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) experiments were performed in a flow setup using 4.63 vol% H2 in Ar at a flow rate of 84.1sccm. The H2 concentration in the exhaust gas was monitored by a thermal conductivity detector (Hydros 100, Fisher-Rosemount). The reactor loaded with about 40mg of the sample was heated from room temperature to 200°C with a heating rate of 2°C/min and held for 30min before cooling down. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were performed in a UHV set up equipped with a monochromated Al K α X-ray source (1486.6eV, 14.5kV, 30.5mA) as incident radiation and a Gammadata-Scienta SES 2002 hemispherical analyzer. The base pressure in the measurement chamber was 5×10− 10 mbar. A pass energy of 200eV and a slit width of 0.2mm were chosen resulting in an energy resolution better than 0.6eV. Charging effects were compensated using a flood gun, and binding energies were calibrated using the main C 1 s peak at 284.5eV as internal standard. A Gaussian–Lorentzian mixed function with a ratio of 70:30 and a Shirley background were applied in spectra deconvolution. 2.3 Electrochemical tests Electrocatalytic tests were performed in a conventional three-electrode cell controlled by an Autolab potentiostat/galvanostat (PGSTAT12, Eco Chemie) in combination with a Metrohm RDE-2 rotator and its control unit. A home-made Ag/AgCl, 3M KCl electrode (+ 0.210V versus NHE) and a platinum wire served as the reference electrode (RE) and counter electrode (CE), respectively. Polished glassy carbon (GC) disc electrodes (diameter: 3.8mm) embedded in a Teflon cylinder were employed as working electrodes (WE). The catalyst suspension was prepared by ultrasonically dispersing the catalyst (5.0mg) in a mixture of water (490mL), ethanol (490mL) and Nafion® (5 %, 20mL). Subsequently, the resulting catalyst suspension was dropped onto the polished GC electrode to obtain a catalyst loading of 210µg/cm2. The electrode was dried in air at room temperature before measurement. Prior to the measurements, the electrolyte KOH (0.1M) was purged with pure O2 for 20min to reach O2 saturation. All the modified electrodes were pre-conditioned by cyclically sweeping in the potential range 1.0–1.5V versus reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) at a scan rate of 100mV/s until reproducible cyclic voltammograms (CV) were obtained. Linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) was performed at a scan rate of 5mV/s and a rotation speed of 1600rpm. Tafel plots were obtained from LSV recorded at a scan rate of 1mV/s and a rotation speed of 1600rpm. All the potentials were corrected for IR drop and are reported versus the RHE. Unless explicitly stated, all the current densities reported in this work were calculated using the geometric area of the electrode. The long-term stability was investigated using the catalysts deposited on glassy carbon electrodes in 0.1M KOH following a procedure combining CV, electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS), and chronopotentiometric polarization. The chronopotentiometric procedure involved polarization at a current density of 3mA/cm2 for 30min, followed by intermediate CV (at 100mV/s), LSV (at 5mV/s) and EIS measurements, in that order, repeating for 10 cycles. EIS measurements were recorded in the frequency range from 50kHz to 10Hz using an AC perturbation of 10mV (rms) at the open circuit potential of the electrode. The RDE electrode was set at 1600rpm in the entire course of the stability measurements while it was kept stationary during EIS measurements. The electrolyte was purged for 20min with O2 prior to each measurement, and the O2 flow was maintained at 30mL/min over the surface of the electrolyte during the experiment. All the measurements were carried out at room temperature. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization The as-received CNTs were purified by washing with 1.5M nitric acid before the deposition of RuO2. Elemental analysis found traces of residual metals (Co and Mn) in OCNTs and NCNTs (Table 1). The specific surface area of the modified CNTs was obtained by N2 physisorption. The one-step CVD method consisting of mixing the precursor and substrate and subsequent thermal treatment turned out to be a simple and effective method for the deposition of RuO2 on CNTs. The Ru content in RuO2/OCNTs and RuO2/NCNTs was determined to be 9.8 wt% and 10.1 wt%, respectively (Table 1), very close to the theoretical Ru loading of 10 wt%. After RuO2 deposition, the specific surface area of OCNTs decreased from 290m2/g to 227m2/g, while that of the NCNTs decreased from 309 to 259m2/g. The structure of the as-prepared samples was investigated by XRD. Fig. 1 shows the XRD patterns of RuO2/OCNTs, RuO2/NCNTs and the corresponding CNT substrates. The reflections at 25.9°, 42.8°, 53.1° and 77.8° 2θ originate from the (002), (100), (004) and (110) planes of the hexagonal graphite structure, respectively. The major reflections at around 28.0°, 35.0°, 40.0° and 54.1° 2θ are assigned to the (110), (101), (200), and (211) planes of RuO2, while the minor contributions at 57.8°, 59.4°, 65.6°, 66.9°, 69.5° and 74.1° 2θ are attributed to the (220), (002) and (310) (112), (301), (202) planes of RuO2. The XRD results confirm the presence of crystalline RuO2 in the nanocomposites. Fig. 2 shows representative TEM images and the corresponding particle size distributions of the RuO2 nanoparticles on the CNT supports. The particle size of RuO2 appears to be similar on both OCNTs and NCNTs. Statistical analysis of the particle sizes was carried out by measuring 200–230 particles in several TEM images. The histograms show that the RuO2 nanoparticles on NCNTs are slightly smaller than those on OCNTs. Based on the statistical analysis, the mean RuO2 particle diameters on OCNTs and NCNTs were determined to be 13.9±4.9nm and 13.4±5.4nm, respectively. Fig. 3 presents the H2-TPR profiles of RuO2/OCNTs and RuO2/NCNTs. The peak temperature of RuO2/NCNTs is 5°C lower than that of RuO2/OCNTs, which can be tentatively attributed to the slightly smaller particle size of RuO2 on NCNTs. Due to the relatively large particle size, a direct influence of the support on the reducibility of RuO2 is considered negligible. The chemical state of Ru in the RuO2/CNT samples was investigated by XPS (Fig. 4). Fig. 4(a) displays the C 1 s and Ru 3d spectra. Due to the overlap of C 1 s and Ru 3d 3/2, spectral deconvolution of Ru 3d is difficult. It can be seen from Fig. 4(a) that the main Ru 3d 5/2 peak in the two composites was centered at 280.9eV implying that the chemical state of Ru is mainly 4+ [20,21]. Ru 3p spectra are shown in Fig. 4(b), where the Ru 3p 3/2 peak can be deconvoluted into two peaks at 463.4eV for RuO2 and at 466.4eV for hydrous RuO2 [22]. The relative concentrations of Ru species obtained by deconvoluting the Ru 3p 3/2 spectra are presented in Fig. 4(c). A higher concentration of hydrous RuO2 was observed for RuO2/NCNTs. Fig. 5(a,b) shows the O 1 s spectra of the two CNTs before and after loading with RuO2 nanoparticles. Deconvolution of the O 1 s spectra of the CNTs with RuO2 (Fig. 5a,b) yields three peaks: O–C in phenol and ethers at 533.3eV, O=C in ketones, quinones and aldehydes at 531.2eV, and O2− in RuO2 at 529.5eV [22, 23]. The surface oxygen species on RuO2 such as hydroxide (532eV) and adsorbed H2O (533eV) also contribute to the O 1 s peak [24]. Therefore, the slight increase in the intensity of the O 1 s spectra after RuO2 loading may be assigned to hydroxide formation and H2O adsorption on the deposited RuO2 nanoparticles, which is in good agreement with the deconvolution of the Ru 3p 3/2 spectra. In addition, the N 1 s spectra of NCNTs before and after loading with RuO2 nanoparticles are presented in Fig. 5(c). The N 1 s spectrum was deconvoluted into two peaks at 398.5eV and 400.5eV attributed to pyridinic (N1) and pyrrolic (N2) nitrogen species, respectively [25]. A decrease in the intensity of the nitrogen species was observed for the NCNTs after RuO2 deposition, implying that N-containing groups are the preferred anchoring sites for RuO2. 3.2 Electrochemical performance The electrocatalytic performance of OCNTs, NCNTs, RuO2/OCNTs and RuO2/NCNTs supported on glassy carbon electrodes was evaluated by LSV in 0.1M KOH at a scan rate of 5mV/s with electrode rotation at 1600rpm. Prior to recording LSV, the electrodes were first conditioned by continuous potential cycling between 1.0V and 1.5V until reproducible voltammograms were obtained. The stabilized CVs of all the samples are presented in Fig. 6(a), where NCNTs and RuO2/NCNTs show higher double layer capacitances (C DL) than OCNTs and RuO2/OCNTs, respectively. On the one hand, surface functionalization of CNTs with nitrogen improves the basicity and electrical conductivity of CNTs, responsible for the higher C DL of the NCNTs. On the other hand, hydrous RuO2 possesses mixed proton–electron conductivity and high specific capacitance. Estimation of the changes of C DL of OCNTs and NCNTs before and after RuO2 deposition reveals a higher C DL for RuO2/NCNTs. Typical OER results of the catalysts are presented in Fig. 6(b) and Table 2. It can be seen that NCNT-supported RuO2 shows remarkably improved electrocatalytic activity compared with RuO2/OCNTs in terms of onset potentials and OER potentials at 10mA/cm2, suggesting a promoting effect of nitrogen on the OER activity of RuO2. The CNTs without RuO2 nanoparticles show very low electrocatalytic activity for the OER as indicated by comparably much larger overpotentials to reach the same current density. For example, the overpotential required for a current density of 10mA/cm2 was 0.35V and 0.38V when using RuO2/NCNTs and RuO2/OCNTs, respectively, while it was 0.52V for both bare OCNTs and NCNTs. The activity of functionalized CNTs can be attributed to the surface oxygen- and nitrogen-functional groups, as well as the residual metal species from CNT production process [26–28]. Evaluation of the kinetics of OER was performed using Tafel plots, which are extensively used for the evaluation of the kinetics of electrode reactions [29]. The Tafel equation is presented in Eq. (1): (1) η = a + b log i where a = 2 . 303 R T α n F log i 0 , i 0 is the exchange current density, b = − 2 . 303 R T α n F is the Tafel slope from which the rate-determining step of an electrode-catalyzed reaction and thus its mechanism can be inferred. The Tafel plots were derived from LSVs recorded at a slow scan rate of 1mV/s and at rotation rate of 1600rpm in 0.1M KOH. The Tafel slopes were obtained from the linear region of the Tafelplots (Fig. 6c). The slope generally gives insight into the nature of the rate-limiting elementary step during oxygen evolution. It is considered that the Tafel slope is around 118mV/dec, when the kinetics of the reaction is limited by a step involving both charge transfer and a chemical process, while it is about 59mV/dec when the rate-limiting step involves a charge transfer step [29,30]. Two different Tafel slopes can be observed for all the catalysts, indicating a change in the rate-determining step, that is, ∼ 60mV/dec in the low-potential region (< 1.52V) and ∼ 120mV/dec in the high-potential region (> 1.52V). NCNT-supported RuO2 shows slightly lower Tafel slopes in both potential regions than RuO2/OCNTs indicating favorable kinetics due to the improved electrical conductivity of CNTs by N-doping [31]. In addition, CNTs after loading with RuO2 showed a remarkable decrease in the Tafel slopes in the low potential region. The potential at 10mA/cm2 and the corresponding overpotentials (η) as well as the derived Tafel slopes are summarized in Table 2 for comparison. The Nyquist plots at OCP for all the samples are shown in Fig. 6(d). Essentially, no differences between NCNTs and OCNTs can be found in the impedance data. Measuring interfacial charge transfer, usually as charge transfer resistance under actual measuring conditions, provides a very reliable means of studying the conductivity of electrocatalytic materials. This works particularly well for an electrode at open circuit potential in the presence of a fast reversible redox mediator. For the present catalysts, which are all highly conductive, these differences are not easy to resolve especially for a very irreversible reaction such as the oxygen evolution reaction. The EIS data was thus only used for determining the solution resistance, which was subsequently used for iR drop correction. The electrochemical stability of a given electrocatalyst is of great importance for practical applications. The stability of the two CNT supports was probed chrono potentiometrically at a current density of 3mA/cm2 as described in the experimental section. The initial OER potential of each galvanostatic step recorded at 3mA/cm2 was used as a reference for OER stability (Fig. 7a). In order to monitor interfacial changes of C DL, which is commonly used to evaluate the stability of electrocatalysts [32], cyclic voltammograms were carried out after each galvanostatic step. For both OCNTs and NCNTs, the OER overpotentials increased with the number of galvanostatic cycles, and the C DL as well as the electrocatalytic current during OER current decreased dramatically. The poor stability of OCNTs and NCNTsis ascribed to carbon corrosion (Eq. 2). Due to the large curvature of the graphene sheets or edge planes, the CNT tips and surface defects are particularly considered the preferential sites for electrochemical carbon oxidation [32]. (2) C+4OH‒→CO2+2H2O+4e‒ Fig. 8 presents the chronopotentiometric response and cyclic voltammograms of RuO2/OCNTs and RuO2/NCNTs. Increase in overpotential of 41mV and 30mV after 5h of continuous galvanostatic polarization at 3mA/cm2 was observed for RuO2/OCNTs and RuO2/NCNTs, respectively (Fig. 8a). The higher C DL of RuO2/NCNTs is presumably due to a higher concentration of hydrous RuO2 on NCNTs and surface nitrogen-containing functional groups, as revealed by the XPS (Figs. 4,5) and CV (Fig. 6a) studies. Since C DL is proportional to the electrochemically active surface area of an electrode, monitoring changes in the C DL can provide valuable information about the stability of the electrode materials, in this case RuO2 nanoparticles and CNTs. The redox features between 1.3V and 1.4V in CVs (Fig. 8b,c) originate from the reversible transition between Ru(VI) and Ru(VII) [33]. In addition to the normal double layer charge, ruthenium oxide is also known to reversibly exchange protons with the electrolyte during redox transition from the Ru(IV) to the Ru(V) state and vice versa. It can be seen that NCNT-supported RuO2 possesses better stability as indicated by the chronopotentiometric response, the C DL and intensity of the Ru(VI)/Ru(VII) redox waves, thus indicating a stabilizing effect on the RuO2 nanoparticles by the nitrogen groups present on the surface of the NCNTs. Moreover, comparing the voltammograms of the two CNT supports before (Fig. 7) and after loading with RuO2 nanoparticles (Fig. 8) shows dramatically improved stability of C DL and Ru(VI)/Ru(VII) redox waves under the same current densities, which confirms that at low overpotential during OER, the availability of sufficient RuO2 nanoparticles precludes severe electrochemical oxidation of carbon. Carbon corrosion is a critical problem for electrocatalysis with carbon-containing electrode materials especially for oxidation reactions like the OER. However, as shown in this work, by using a highly active noble metal catalyst like RuO2, which is able to catalyze the OER at low overpotentials, carbon corrosion can be largely avoided. Further, the presence of nitrogen-containing functional groups showed a stabilizing effect on the supported RuO2 nanoparticles. 4 Conclusions RuO2 nanoparticles supported on OCNTs and NCNTs were synthesized using the MOCVD method. Slightly smaller RuO2 nanoparticles with a mean particle diameter of 13.4±5.4nm were formed on the NCNT support with an N content of 0.97 wt% compared with 13.9±4.9nm for OCNTs. The OER activity and stability were investigated using LSV, CV, and chronopotentiometry. The overpotentials, Tafel slopes, double layer capacitances and the chronopotentiometric results demonstrate that both the OER activity and the long-term stability of RuO2 nanoparticles supported on NCNTs are significantly higher than on OCNTs, indicating a promoting effect of the nitrogen-containing functional groups, which can be attributed to the improved conductivity of CNTs by N-doping and the higher concentration of hydrous RuO2. The presence of highly active RuO2 nanoparticles was found to preclude the severe electrochemical oxidation of carbon. coredata.dc:description: RuO2 nanoparticles supported on multi-walled carbon nanotubes (CNTs) functionalized with oxygen (OCNTs) and nitrogen (NCNTs) were employed for the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) in 0.1M KOH. The catalysts were synthesized by metal-organic chemical vapor deposition using ruthenium carbonyl (Ru3(CO)12) as Ru precursor. The obtained RuO2/OCNT and RuO2/NCNT composites were characterized using TEM, H2-TPR, XRD and XPS in order probe structure–activity correlations, particularly, the effect of the different surface functional groups on the electrochemical OER performance. The electrocatalytic activity and stability of the catalysts with mean RuO2 particle sizes of 13–14nm was evaluated by linear sweep voltammetry, cyclic voltammetry, and chronopotentiometry, showing that the generation of nitrogen-containing functional groups on CNTs was beneficial for both OER activity and stability. In the presence of RuO2, carbon corrosion was found to be significantly less severe.
